Literature Review: The plant microbiota, comprising the diverse microbial communities associated with plants, has emerged as a crucial factor in sustainable crop production. This literature review explores the intricate relationship between host plant genetics and the microbiota, focusing on how crop domestication and diversification have shaped these interactions and their potential applications in agriculture.Plant domestication and crop diversification have significantly influenced the genetic determinants of microbiota recruitment. Pérez-Jaramillo et al. (2016) demonstrated that modern cultivars of common bean (Phaseolus vulgaris) exhibited distinct rhizosphere bacterial communities compared to their wild relatives, suggesting that domestication has altered plant-microbe interactions. Similarly, Zachow et al. (2014) found that different cultivars of sugar beet (Beta vulgaris) recruited distinct microbial communities, highlighting the role of plant genotype in shaping the microbiota.The heritable component of microbiota recruitment is increasingly recognized as a potential target for crop improvement. Walters et al. (2018) conducted a comprehensive study on maize (Zea mays) and found that approximately 5-7% of the variation in rhizosphere microbiome composition could be attributed to host genetics. This finding underscores the potential for breeding crops with enhanced abilities to recruit beneficial microbes. However, the environment plays a crucial role in modulating the magnitude of this heritability. Edwards et al. (2015) observed that the heritability of root-associated bacterial communities in rice (Oryza sativa) varied across different field conditions, emphasizing the need to consider environmental factors in microbiota-based breeding strategies.Recent studies have begun to treat host-microbiota interactions as external quantitative traits, associating crop genetics with microbiota-based phenotypes. Wagner et al. (2016) identified quantitative trait loci (QTLs) in Arabidopsis thaliana that influenced the composition of root-associated bacterial communities, providing a genetic basis for microbiome assembly. In a landmark study, Bergelson et al. (2019) conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) in A. thaliana, revealing numerous plant loci associated with the abundance of specific bacterial taxa in the rhizosphere.To establish causal relationships between microbiota and plant phenotypes, researchers have employed reductionist approaches using synthetic microbial communities. Bai et al. (2015) demonstrated that a synthetic community of root-derived bacteria could protect Arabidopsis against foliar pathogens, illustrating the potential of engineered microbiomes for crop protection. In a similar vein, Finkel et al. (2017) used synthetic communities to show that specific bacterial consortia could enhance drought tolerance in tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) plants.The integration of microbiota manipulation into crop selection programs represents a promising frontier in agricultural research. Gopal and Gupta (2016) proposed a framework for incorporating microbiome-based traits into plant breeding pipelines, emphasizing the need for high-throughput phenotyping methods and advanced genomic tools. Building on this concept, Toju et al. (2018) outlined strategies for engineering plant-associated microbiomes to enhance crop productivity and resilience.Despite these advances, challenges remain in fully harnessing the potential of plant-microbiota interactions for crop improvement. One key obstacle is the complex nature of microbiome assembly, which is influenced by both host genetics and environmental factors. Fitzpatrick et al. (2018) highlighted the importance of considering the holobiont (plant and its associated microbiome) as a unit of selection in plant breeding programs, emphasizing the need for a systems-level approach to crop improvement.In conclusion, while a comprehensive understanding of how to leverage microbiota heritability for breeding purposes is still developing, recent advances in crop genomics and microbiome research are paving the way for wider applications of plant-microbiota interactions in agriculture. As our knowledge of the genetic basis of microbiota recruitment and function expands, we can anticipate the development of novel breeding strategies that harness the power of the plant microbiome to enhance crop productivity, resilience, and sustainability.
